clean_story:
"Digital money. No banks needed. "

"Cryptocurrency" mixes "crypto" (hidden codes) and "currency" (money). It’s like trading rare Pokémon cards online—except the cards are math, not paper. <[silence:2400]

Most money lives in banks. Crypto lives on a shared ledger called a blockchain—a digital notebook everyone can check, but no one can erase.
Bitcoin, the first crypto, launched in 2009. Its creator, Satoshi Nakamoto, vanished after writing: "I’m moving on to other things. " No one knows who they are.

Crypto works like a vending machine: You put in regular money, press buttons (buy/sell), and get digital coins. Miners—computers solving puzzles—keep the system running, earning crypto as payment.
Example: In 2010, a programmer bought two pizzas for 10,000 Bitcoin. Today, those Bitcoins would buy 600 million pizzas.

Three related subjects are smart contracts, decentralized finance, and NFT ownership proofs.
